messageBody:
<disclaimer>
What follows is a shameless plug for a real Object-Oriented
language, one that is much better than the knock-off Java
that many of us are forced to program in on a regular basis.
</disclaimer>

If you are *really* interested in a language that will help you to
understand Objects better than any language out there, Smalltalk is the
way to go. That being said the flavor of the day is definitely Squeak,
an open source implementation of the Smalltalk-80 system (www.squeak.org
-- a minimal front-end to the community). As far as IDEs go, Smalltalk
was and continues to be the leader for many reasons, but since this
isn't a Smalltalk list, I will leave it there to whet your appetite. By
the way, in case you didn't know, JUnit is the Java equivalent of the
original XUnit testing framework by Kent Beck called SUnit (Smalltalk
Unit), and Squeak is fully up-to-date with the latest and greatest on
that front as well.

=jason

Here is a list of books and resources I've found very inspirational
(the numbers indicate an ordening in terms of phases).

Java seems to me one of the most suitable languages for concentrating on
learning OO.

Unit testing and refactoring are also very advisable techniques to use
and
know about as soon as possible.

(Furthermore, using ANT and a nice IDE like IntelliJ IDEA should settle
you
for a pleasant OO cruise.)

(*) is probably one of the best introductions to OO

a.. book: Design Patterns, (GoF) (2)
b.. book: Craig Larman, "Applying UML and Patterns" (2) (*)
c.. Martin Fowler:
a.. http://martinfowler.com/articles.html
b.. book: "UML Distilled: A Brief Guide to the Standard Object
Modeling
Language" (2)
c.. book: "Analysis Patterns : Reusable Object Models" (3)
d.. book: "Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code" (3)
d.. unit testing: http://www.junit.org/ (1)
e.. refactoring: www.refactoring.com (2)
f.. ANT: http://jakarta.apache.org/ant/antnews.html
g.. programming in Java:
h.. book: Bruce Eckel, "Thinking in Java, 2nd Edition (1)
i.. Java @ Sun (1)
AG

Bringing a newbie into OO
=========================

I would like to ask the people on this list for recommendations of the
best
literature to bring an OO newbie up to speed.

The programming language in question is Java, which means that there
is a
splendid wealth of online material for someone to learn the language.
The
important thing, however, is to instill the notion of OO purity, which
is
harder, perhaps, than just teaching the language.

For example: the GoF patterns book is a must, but I think it is not a
text
that you can give to someone until they have a grounding in OO
techniques.

Your thoughts?

Manuel Amago.
